review.title: Revisiting Selectional Preferences for Coreference Resolution
review.abstract: Selectional preferences have long been claimed to be essential for coreference resolution. However, they are mainly modeled only implicitly by current coreference resolvers. We propose a dependency-based embedding model of selectional preferences which allows fine-grained compatibility judgments with high coverage. We show that the incorporation of our model improves coreference resolution performance on the CoNLL dataset, matching the state-of-the-art results of a more complex system. However, it comes with a cost that makes it debatable how worthwhile such improvements are.

metadata.title: Revisiting Selectional Preferences for Coreference Resolution

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In his groundbreaking work "Dissolving Pronominal References" (1978), he proposed a semantic approach that required consideration of the "requirements of the predicate for its arguments." "It is plausible that a ship will be sunk, but it is implausible that an iceberg will be sunk." Work on automatic preference capture has made considerable progress (Dagan and Itai, 1993).

sections.heading: 2 Modeling Selectional Preferences
sections.text: The most important design choice in modeling selective representations is probably the selection of a relationship inventory, i.e. the concepts and entities that can be relation arguments, and the semantic relationships that are seen between them. Prior's work has examined many relationships. However, predicate reasoning statistics for word-word pairs (eat, eat) 1 are easy to obtain but not generalize pairs (Agirre and Martinez), but require a disambiguation of words into classes and are limited by the coverage of the lexical resource that such classes provide (e.g. WordNet).Other possible relationship inventories include semantic representations such as FrameNet and roles, event type types, and abstract representations.

sections.heading: 3 Implementation
sections.text: We train our model by combining term context pairs from two sources. Term context pairs are extracted from GigaWord (Parker et al., 2011) and entity types in context from Wikilinks (Singh et al., 2012). Term context pairs are obtained by analyzing each corpus with the Stanford CoreNLP dependency saver (Manning et al., 2014). After filtering, we obtain approximately 1.4 billion phrase context pairs such as (Titanic, sank @ nsubj) from GigaWord and approximately 12.9 million entity type context pairs such as (/ product / ship, sank @ nsubj) from Wikilinks. Finally, we train dependency-based embeddings using the generalized word2vec version of Levy and Goldberg (2014), obtaining distributed representations of selective preferences.

sections.heading: 4 Do Selectional Preferences Benefit Coreference Resolution?
sections.text: We investigate the effects of selective preferences, implicitly and explicitly, on the nature of people who are able to identify themselves. It shows that people who are able to identify themselves, identify themselves, identify themselves, identify themselves, identify themselves, identify themselves, identify themselves, identify themselves, identify themselves, identify themselves, identify themselves, identify themselves, identify themselves, think, act, think, think, think, act, think, act, act, think, act, think, think, act, think, act, think, act, act, act, act, act, think, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, think, think, act, think, act, act, act, think, act, act, act, act, think, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, identify, identify, identify, identify, identify, identify, identify, identify, identify, identify, identify, identify, think, identify, think, identify, identify, act, act, act, act, act, act, think, act, think, act, act, think, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, and act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, act, and act, act, act, act, act, act, identify, identify, identify, identify, identify, identify, identify, identify, identification, identify, identify, identify, identify, identification, identification, identification, identification, identification, identification, identification, identification, identification, identification, identification, identification, identification, identification

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: We are introducing a new model of selective preferences that combines dependency-based word embedding and fine-grained entity types. To be effective, a selective preference model (1) should have high coverage so that it can be used for large datasets such as CoNLL, and (2) can be combined with other knowledge sources in a non-linear manner. Our selective preference model slightly improves the performance of the correlation resolution, but given the additional resources required to train the model, it is questionable whether such small improvements are beneficial for solving the correlation.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: The authors thank the three anonymous reviewers for their helpful comments. This work was supported by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG, German Research Foundation) within the framework of the Research Training Group Adaptive Processing of Information from Heterogeneous Sources (AIPHES) within the framework of RTG 1994 / 1 and the Klaus Tschira Foundation, Heidelberg.

metadata.abstractText: Selectional preferences have long been claimed to be essential for coreference resolution. However, they are mainly modeled only implicitly by current coreference resolvers. We propose a dependencybased embedding model of selectional preferences which allows fine-grained compatibility judgments with high coverage. We show that the incorporation of our model improves coreference resolution performance on the CoNLL dataset, matching the state-of-the-art results of a more complex system. However, it comes with a cost that makes it debatable how worthwhile such improvements are.
